awd_titl_txt: Travel: FLAIRS Conference Experience for Workforce Development in Artificial Intelligence
awd_abstract_narration:
Artificial Intelligence (A.I.) permeates many aspects of our lives. With this growth - accelerated in the last year through the popularity of platforms such as ChatGPT - industry and academia have put a premium on recruiting students and employees that can design, implement, test, and use A.I. models and approaches. Unfortunately, tied somewhat to the need for more students in the general field of computer science, there is a lack of skilled workers in the field of A.I. In addition, the lack of diversity in the computational fields, especially when it comes to women and minorities, has led to a lack of diversity in the thought and design of A.I. systems, introducing bias into models and systems. However, providing exposure to A.I. can be problematic, especially for students from economically disadvantaged or rural communities and institutions. In short, there is a need for concerted efforts to recruit a diverse set of students and workers to the growing field of artificial intelligence. This project will support the participation of a diverse set of students to attend the second oldest artificial intelligence conference in the United States, the Florida Artificial Intelligence Research Society (FLAIRS) conference, in May 2024.

The objective of this proposal is to serve the NSF’s interest in advancing science through increasing interest and workforce development in artificial intelligence. The plan is to host 15 who represent a diverse demographic, especially among women, minorities, and persons with disabilities, from multiple universities, including those that consist primarily of economically disadvantaged students.  The students can participate in a range of tutorials and engage with researchers and others in the field.  A clear plan focuses on universities and colleges in the southeast region of the US.  Clear evaluation is provided.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Artificial Intelligence (A.I.) permeates many aspects of our lives. Very recently, industry and academia have put a premium on recruiting students and employees that can design, implement, test, and use A.I. models and approaches. Unfortunately, tied somewhat to the need for more students in the general field of computer science, there is a lack of skilled workers in the field of A.I. The objective of this project was to serve the NSF’s interest in advancing science through increasing student interest and workforce development in artificial intelligence. For this project, we hosted 12 students at the Florida Artificial Intelligence Research Society (FLAIRS) conference in May 2024. These students represented a diverse demographic, especially among women, and minorities, from multiple universities, including those that consist primarily of economically disadvantaged students. Through the conference’s main track sessions, special track sessions, tutorials, and keynote speakers, the student participants were exposed to a wide variety of research and development areas in artificial intelligence. In order to evaluate the effectiveness of this proposal, the PIs administered two surveys among the student participants: one before attending the conference and one after attending the conference. In addition, this cohort of students attended a special breakout session, where they met other FLAIRS leaders and learned about their involvement in A.I. The objective of this proposal is to serve the NSF’s interest in advancing science through increasing interest and workforce development in artificial intelligence.

Since the objective of this proposal is to increase interest and workforce development in artificial intelligence, the surveys (pre-conference and post-conference) consisted of questions (on a Likert scale), including:

-              What is your interest in pursuing a career in artificial intelligence?

-              What is your interest in doing research in artificial intelligence?

-              If an undergraduate, what is your interest in learning skills related to artificial intelligence?

-              What is your interest in pursuing a graduate degree in artificial intelligence?

10 participants fully completed the pre-survey with 4 identifying as female and 6 identifying as male and with 4 being undergraduate students and 6 being graduate students. All 12 participants fully completed the post-survey with 5 identifying as female, 6 identifying as male, and 1 identifying as non-binary and with 6 being undergraduate students and 6 being graduate students. The above questions appeared on both the pre- and post-surveys. Interest in pursuing a career in AI/ML increased in all comparison groups except for males, where it remained unchanged. Overall, interest in doing research in AI/ML increased very slightly with a larger increase in interest among females and a decrease among males. Interest among undergraduates was unchanged with a slight increase among graduate students. Interest in pursuing a graduate degree in AI/ML increased among all comparison groups. Interest in learning skills related to AI/ML was unchanged or decreased very slightly in all comparison groups other than females among whom it increased. It is noteworthy that among the demographic groups we analyzed, those identifying as female consistently had the largest increase in interest and were the only group with an increase in interest in every area about which we asked.

The post-survey asked 3 additional questions:

-          As a result of the conference, I learned a new skill(s) related to artificial intelligence/machine learning

-          As a result of the conference, I learned how one does research in artificial intelligence/machine learning

-          As a result of the conference, I learned about career opportunities related to artificial intelligence/machine learning

For the first additional question, all groups either “strongly agreed” or “somewhat agreed” with the strongest agreement among females. For the second additional question, scores were uniformly high with 8 strongly agrees and 4 somewhat agrees. However, the last additional question had mixed results, still with a majority of strongly agrees but also with a strongly disagree and a somewhat disagree. This last result is not too surprising given that there is not a significant career component to the FLAIRS conference.

Overall, the success of the project will ultimately be based upon whether or not it increases student enrollment in undergraduate A.I. programs, pursuit of graduate degrees in A.I., and/or participation in the A.I. workforce.

 


Last Modified: 07/02/2024
Modified by: William Eberle
